content:
This is a personal opinion but you seem to take these well.

This puzzle is no way an easy one. "Researching online what a Markov chain is, what an n-gram is, and how to apply this to text is part of your quest." <- This sentence alone indicates how much it is not the case, An easy task -- in my opinion -- is a good stepping stone for beginners, i.e it should not involve extensive search to understand the task plus possible search for programming constructs (I think most people solve this with some sort of dictionary construct). And while both skills are important they are not easy.

Also having example for word_count(seed) > depth is an edge case that is not trivial to notice why it fails.

And I do understand the number of lines to code this is rather low and with enough experience the given example is sufficient to know what to do but that's not a reason to make this easy. There is a Hard problem here in CG for which I constructed a closed formula in 5 minutes that solved it. Does that make it easy? No, I have a PhD in Mathematics and saw similar tasks many times. People tend to forget in the comment section that pre-existing knowledge makes things look easy. And I too, like others solved this in less than 10 minutes with ease and quite liked all the concepts but difficulty should not be based on that.

And to finish it off, it is a great puzzle, I really liked it, especially how rare these days seem to be to have a well-written description.

The puzzle pointed out by Zorg1 has been added as a reference at the end of the description and differences noted.  Thanks for the link Zorg1
this puzzle seems to be a variation of this puzzle : https://www.codingame.com/training/hard/code-your-own-automaton2000-step-1

I rated it as "Difficulty: Medium".  There is another puzzle that uses Markov that is "Hard".  This puzzle explains a lot of the steps and introduces a random function.   This certainly does not need anything as complicated as recursion or a constraint solver or search like DFS.

My rules of thumb for difficulty is as follows : 
* if/else and possibly a loop is 'easy'.  
* Recursion, DFS, BFS, Minimax is 'medium'.  
* Tricky or mathy stuff with multiple steps is 'hard' or 'very hard'

Not quite.  That code uses a tree, not a Markov chain.  The only similarity is that the backstory is 'Automaton2000' and the topic of text generation.  The algorithm and approach is entirely different.
Yes, I think you may be right about the difficulty

This is great feedback.  Thanks.  I have changed the difficulty back and forth between medium and easy many times as it was a very hard call for me.  I think it would be good to find a few puzzles that are around the same difficulty and go from there.  I completely agree about your comments regarding lines of code being unrelated to difficulty.

I'm watching the % complete number.  if that drops too low, then probably it should be re-classified as medium.  Currently it is at 83% with about 40 people successfully completing it.  That's actually pretty high.

With an easy puzzle that's probably a rather nice way to get some sense of it.

I'm also happy that you put this much thought and care into your puzzle. I've solved many where the combined effort weren't even close to this one. Or the combined description that made sense...
Good point about a repeat of theme and backstory.  I'll make a change so that it has a different backstory and not repeat Automaton2000

Using tree is another method to implement a markov chain.
Ok in the referenced puzzle the depth is only 1
The difference of your puzzle is that you use different depth, and a different start seed.

I thought the referenced puzzle wasn't depth 1, but depth in the tree.  Also, the referenced puzzled does not use a random selection.  I'll make some time to solve the other puzzle to double check, but it seems like a tree vs an n-gram would produce very different results.

Zorg1 , you are correct.  The linked puzzle is indeed an 1-gram and not a tree.  Here are the notable differences then:

1 - the starting seed is variable (not just __START__)
2 - the ngram depth is variable (not just 1)
3 - a random like traversal is added (not just highest frequency)

I upvoted your responses.  Thanks for finding the related puzzle.

I had almost forgotten about this one.
Yes, Zorg1 is generally right.
There are a few other differences though. 
The present one makes terms like markov chain and n-grams explicit. 
The original one is a bit tricky to implement - it uses string manipulation, building the three and producing the output happens simultaneously, and has edge cases.
I guess arguments can be made in both directions - that it is too similar/has its own justification.
As I see it this one is more conceptually clear (educational) and the original one is more like a concrete application of the idea (mimicking a chat bot).
I do not mind having both of them on CG. 
(As a side note - maybe this one can accommodate characters as n-grams).
I've added the other puzzle as a link and have also changed the difficulty to medium
Thank you for finding that.  I've fixed the broken unit test.
